The DevOps Contradictionary

  • agile development: the ability of a development team to nimbly shift blame for any faults in their product to the customer, operations, management, the shareholders, regulators, or competitors, as appropriate to each specific failure.
  • CI/CD pipeline: a high-speed method for getting your latest bugs out into production.
  • containerization: the idea that, if all of the flaws in one's product are tightly bundled into a "container," then there is really only one flaw present.
  • continuous deployment: the attempt by IT to subject the business to a stream of bugs so relentless that the business will passively submit to whatever bugs come next.
  • data science: a subset of mine engineering, one which studies the process of extracting enormous fees from corporate customers using only a minimal knowledge of statistics and the ability to create a Python notebook.
  • integration testing: automated tests to determine if an IT department has a sufficient number of representatives of various trendy categories of employee.
  • kanban board: a project management technique based on the idea that, if a development group is faced with an impossible-to-fulfill set of demands, putting each demand on a post-it note will enable the group to finish them all in a timely fashion.
  • repository: a single, unique place in which every error made in developing a project can be collected: for the business, quite similar to a suppository.
  • The Cloud: an attempt by IT to escape all blame for future data processing disasters by rendering the entire computing infrastructure completely nebulous.
